TextSection.Contents: A rare soft tissue sarcoma originating from vascular endothelial cells, histologically typically characterized by irregular vascular spaces lined by atypical endothelial cells (in well differentiated tumors) or sheets of spindle cells or epithelioid shaped cells with increased mitotic activity (in poorly differentiated tumors). The tumor arises preferentially in elderly individuals in superficial soft tissues and skin, with a predilection for the head and neck region, although all areas of the body may be affected. Macroscopically it typically presents as an ill-defined violaceous plaque which may develop a thicker, nodular surface, including ulceration and hemorrhage as the disease progresses. Angiosarcomas are very aggressive tumors with poor prognosis.
